data.text:
Introduction

The San Antonio Spurs are an American professional basketball team based in San Antonio. The Spurs compete in the National Basketball Association (NBA) as a member of the league’s Western Conference Southwest Division. The team plays its home games at AT&T Center in San Antonio.

The Spurs are one of four former American Basketball Association (ABA) teams to remain intact in the NBA after the 1976 ABA–NBA merger and are the only former ABA team to have won an NBA championship. The franchise has won NBA championships in 1999, 2003, 2005, 2007, and 2014.As of the 2022–23 season, the Spurs had the highest winning percentage among active NBA franchises. As of May 2017, the Spurs had the best winning percentage of any franchise in the major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada over the previous three decades. From 1999–2000 to 2016–17, the Spurs won 50 games each season, setting a record of 18 consecutive 50-win seasons. In the 2018–19 season, the Spurs matched an NBA record for most consecutive playoff appearances with 22. The team’s recent success has coincided with the tenure of current head coach Gregg Popovich and with the playing careers of Spurs icons David Robinson (1989–2003) and Tim Duncan (1997–2016). In the 2022-23 season, the Spurs celebrated the club’s 50th anniversary.

History

1967–1973: Beginnings as the Dallas/Texas Chaparrals

The San Antonio Spurs originated as the Dallas Chaparrals in the American Basketball Association (ABA) from 1967 to 1973. Coached by Cliff Hagan, the Chaparrals were part of the inaugural season of the ABA but had a disappointing second season, finishing fourth with a 41-37 record. They were eliminated in the playoffs by the New Orleans Buccaneers. The team faced challenges with low attendance and lack of interest in Dallas. To expand their regional appeal, the team changed its name to the Texas Chaparrals and played games in Fort Worth and Lubbock during the 1970-71 season. However, this strategy failed, and the team returned to Dallas full-time for the 1971-72 season, playing home games at Moody Coliseum and Dallas Convention Center Arena.

1973–1976: Moving to San Antonio

The Dallas Chaparrals faced financial difficulties and decided to sell the team after their third season in the ABA. A group of San Antonio businessmen, led by Angelo Drossos, John Schaefer, and Red McCombs, entered into a lease agreement with the Dallas ownership group, with an option to purchase the team. They relocated the team to San Antonio, initially naming them the Gunslingers but quickly changing it to the Spurs. The team adopted new colors and played their games at HemisFair Arena.

In their inaugural season in San Antonio, the Spurs showcased a strong defense and attracted a supportive fanbase. They finished with a 45-39 record and made it to the playoffs but were eliminated by the Indiana Pacers. The positive response from San Antonio fans led the ownership group to exercise their option to buy the franchise outright and permanently keep the team in San Antonio.

Under new coach Bob Bass, the Spurs shifted to a fast-paced playing style and experienced further success. They finished the 1974-75 season with a 51-33 record, securing second place in the Western Division. However, they were eliminated in the playoffs by the Pacers once again. Despite not achieving significant playoff success, the Spurs became one of the top teams in the ABA and garnered attention from the NBA.

In 1976, the ABA-NBA merger took place, and the Spurs, along with the Denver Nuggets, Indiana Pacers, and New York Nets, joined the NBA for the 1976-77 season. As part of the merger agreement, the Spurs and the other ABA teams paid financial compensation to the owners of two ABA teams that did not join the NBA. This added financial pressure on the Spurs.

Over time, the Spurs established themselves as a successful NBA franchise in San Antonio, despite being in a medium-sized market. The team’s journey from the ABA to the NBA marked a significant milestone in their history and set the stage for their future accomplishments.

1976–1985: The George Gervin era

After joining the NBA in the 1976-77 season, the San Antonio Spurs proved their worth by finishing with a 44-38 record, tying for fourth place in the Eastern Conference. Despite facing limitations on draft picks and television revenues imposed by the NBA, the Spurs established themselves as a competitive team. They also gained a new rivalry with the Houston Rockets.

In the 1977-78 season, Spurs’ star George Gervin engaged in a scoring battle with David Thompson of the Denver Nuggets for the NBA scoring title. Gervin secured the title by scoring 58 points in the final game, surpassing Thompson’s total. The Spurs won the Central Division with a 52-30 record but were ultimately eliminated in the playoffs by the Washington Bullets.

In the 1979 Conference Finals, the Spurs held a 3-1 lead but ended up losing the series to the Bullets, including a heartbreaking seventh game defeat. It would take another 20 years for the Spurs to reach their first NBA Finals.

During their early years in the NBA, the Spurs achieved success in the regular season, winning five division titles in their first seven years. However, they faced numerous playoff disappointments, losing to teams like the Bullets, Celtics, Rockets, and Lakers.

Throughout the 1980s, the Spurs experienced a mix of highs and lows. They maintained strong regular-season performances but struggled to secure an NBA championship. Despite the presence of star player George Gervin, the team could not advance past the Western Conference playoffs, falling to the Rockets in 1981 and the Lakers in 1982 and 1983.

After the 1984-85 season, Gervin was traded to the Chicago Bulls, signaling the end of an era for the Spurs in San Antonio. The team would have to wait until 1995 to make it to the conference finals again.

1985–1989: Difficult years

The next four seasons were a dark time in Spurs’ history with the team having a combined record of 115–213 from 1985–86 until 1988–89. The losing seasons and dwindling attendance often caused the Spurs to be mentioned as a potential candidate for relocation to another city.

The lone bright spot during this period was the Spurs being awarded the top pick in the 1987 NBA draft through NBA draft lottery. The Spurs used this selection on United States Naval Academy standout David Robinson. Although Robinson was drafted in 1987, the Spurs would have to wait until the 1989–90 season for Robinson to be a Spur because of his prior two-year commitment to serve in the United States Navy.

The Spurs seemingly bottomed out in 1988–89 with a record of 21–61, the worst in franchise history at the time. However, the 1989–90 season was notable for several reasons. It was the first season of full ownership for Red McCombs, who was an original investor in the team and helped solidify local ownership for the team. Additionally, the 1988–89 season featured the debut of Larry Brown as the Spurs head coach who moved to San Antonio after winning the NCAA National Championship with Kansas in 1988.

1989–1997: The David Robinson era

In the late 1980s, David Robinson, a highly anticipated player, decided to join the San Antonio Spurs for the 1989-90 season, ending speculation about him becoming a free agent. The Spurs experienced an incredible turnaround in Robinson’s rookie season, going from the worst record in franchise history to the best. Led by Robinson, Sean Elliott, and Terry Cummings, the team finished with a 56-26 record and won their first division title in seven years. Robinson had a standout rookie season, earning the unanimous Rookie of the Year award.

Throughout the early 1990s, the Spurs consistently made the playoffs but struggled to advance past the second round. They underwent coaching changes, including the firing of head coach Larry Brown midway through the 1991-92 season. The team’s fortunes continued to fluctuate, with a failed experiment with coach Jerry Tarkanian and subsequent hiring of John Lucas, who helped the team reach the Western Conference semi-finals.

In 1993, a group of investors, led by Peter M. Holt, purchased the Spurs from Red McCombs. The team moved to the Alamodome and achieved a 55-27 record in the 1993-94 season under coach John Lucas. However, they were eliminated in the first round of the playoffs, leading to Lucas’ dismissal. The following season, Bob Hill took over as coach, and the Spurs had their best regular-season record at 62-20, with David Robinson being named MVP. They reached the Western Conference Finals but lost to the Houston Rockets, and tension between Dennis Rodman and teammates emerged.

In the 1995-96 season, the Spurs finished with a 59-23 record but fell short in the Western Conference semi-finals. The following season turned out to be disastrous as injuries plagued the team, with Robinson, Elliott, and Chuck Person missing significant playing time. The Spurs ended the season with a 20-62 record, the worst in franchise history, and missed the playoffs for the first time in years.

However, the offseason brought a turnaround for the Spurs. With the worst record in the league, they won the NBA draft lottery and selected Tim Duncan as the first overall pick in the 1997 draft. This marked a significant turning point for the franchise.

1997–2016: The Tim Duncan era

During the late 1990s and early 2000s, the San Antonio Spurs formed a dominant duo known as the “Twin Towers” with David Robinson and Tim Duncan. The duo played together from 1997 to 2003 and led the team to NBA championships in 1999 and 2003.

Duncan had an impressive rookie season in 1997-98, winning the Rookie of the Year award and helping the Spurs improve their record. The team continued to excel with the Twin Towers’ low-post presence on both offense and defense.

In the lockout-shortened 1998-99 season, the Spurs finished with the best record in the NBA and went on to win their first NBA championship. Duncan played a crucial role and was named the NBA Finals MVP as the Spurs defeated the New York Knicks.

In the following seasons, the Spurs remained a top team in the Western Conference, contending for division titles and reaching the playoffs. They faced challenges from the Los Angeles Lakers in the playoffs, including a sweep in the 2001 Conference Finals.

The 2002-03 season marked David Robinson’s final year and the opening of the Spurs’ new arena, the SBC Center. The team underwent changes, with Tony Parker emerging as the starting point guard alongside Duncan. The Spurs had a solid season, finishing with a tie for the best record in the NBA and Duncan earning his second consecutive MVP award.

In the playoffs, the Spurs overcame strong opponents such as the Phoenix Suns, Los Angeles Lakers, and Dallas Mavericks. They ultimately faced the New Jersey Nets in the NBA Finals, winning the series 4-2 and capturing their second NBA championship. Duncan was once again named Finals MVP.

Overall, the Twin Towers era was a highly successful period for the Spurs, marked by consistent playoff appearances, division titles, and two NBA championships.

2003–2016: The “Big Three”

After winning their second NBA Championship, the Spurs experienced retirements and departures, including David Robinson, Steve Kerr, Danny Ferry, Speedy Claxton, and Stephen Jackson.

The team made several key signings, including Rasho Nesterović, Hedo Türkoğlu, and veteran Robert Horry.

The Spurs struggled early in the season but turned it around and finished with a record of 57-25, just one game short of a division title and the best record in the Western Conference.

In the playoffs, they faced the Los Angeles Lakers in the second round and lost in six games.

In the following season, the Spurs acquired Brent Barry, Nazr Mohammed, and Glenn Robinson to bolster their roster.

Tim Duncan suffered an ankle injury during the season, but the Spurs managed to finish with a record of 59-23.

In the playoffs, they went through the Western Conference relatively easily, defeating the Phoenix Suns in the Conference Finals.

In the NBA Finals, they faced the defending champion Detroit Pistons. The series went to Game 7, and the Spurs emerged victorious, winning their third NBA Championship.

The following seasons saw the Spurs consistently performing well, winning division titles and maintaining a strong record.

In the 2006-07 season, they won the Southwest Division with a franchise-best record of 63-19 but were eliminated by the Dallas Mavericks in the second round.

They bounced back in the 2007-08 season, reaching the Western Conference Finals but losing to the Los Angeles Lakers in five games.

The Spurs made several acquisitions in the following years, including Richard Jefferson, DeJuan Blair, and Kawhi Leonard.

In the 2011-12 season, the Spurs had a 20-game winning streak and finished with a record of 50-16, tying the Chicago Bulls for the best record in the league.

They reached the Western Conference Finals but were defeated by the Oklahoma City Thunder.

The Spurs continued to perform well in the subsequent seasons, clinching playoff berths and maintaining their winning culture.

In the 2012-13 season, they reached the NBA Finals but lost to the Miami Heat in a dramatic seven-game series.

The Spurs returned for the 2013-14 season with a record of 62-20, securing the best record in the NBA.

They went on to defeat the Dallas Mavericks, Portland Trail Blazers, and Oklahoma City Thunder to reach the NBA Finals for the second consecutive year.

In the Finals, they faced the Miami Heat once again and achieved redemption, winning the series 4-1 and securing their fifth NBA Championship.

The Spurs remained competitive in the following seasons, but they were unable to capture another championship.

Overall, during this period, the San Antonio Spurs had a highly successful run, winning multiple championships and consistently performing at a high level in the NBA.

2016–present: Post-Duncan era

In the 2016-17 season, despite the retirement of Tim Duncan, the San Antonio Spurs, led by Kawhi Leonard, remained competitive and finished with a record of 61-21. They reached the Western Conference Finals but were swept by the Golden State Warriors, with Leonard getting injured in Game 1.

The following season (2017-18) was overshadowed by tension between Leonard and the Spurs regarding his injury rehabilitation. Leonard missed most of the season and eventually requested a trade. He, along with Danny Green, was traded to the Toronto Raptors in exchange for DeMar DeRozan and others. Tony Parker also left the team and Manu Ginóbili retired.

In the 2018-19 season, the Spurs made the playoffs for the 22nd consecutive time but lost in the first round to the Denver Nuggets. The 2019-20 season was disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic, and the Spurs failed to qualify for the postseason, ending their 22-year playoff streak. The 2020-21 season saw the Spurs miss the playoffs again, and LaMarcus Aldridge left the team mid-season.

After missing the playoffs for two consecutive seasons, the Spurs participated in the play-in tournament in the 2020-21 season but lost to the Memphis Grizzlies. Following the season, DeMar DeRozan was traded, and Patty Mills left in free agency.

On January 13, 2023, the Spurs set a regular season single-game attendance record, and on May 16, 2023, they won the draft lottery, giving them the first pick in the upcoming 2023 NBA draft.

Gregg Popovich

“Coach Pop”

Gregg Popovich is an American basketball coach and executive known for his long and successful tenure as the head coach of the San Antonio Spurs in the NBA. He is considered one of the greatest coaches in NBA history and has the most wins of any coach in NBA history. Popovich has led the Spurs to five NBA championships and has maintained a winning record for 22 consecutive seasons.

Popovich attended the United States Air Force Academy, where he played basketball and graduated with a degree in Soviet studies. He briefly considered a career in the Central Intelligence Agency before pursuing coaching. He began his coaching career as an assistant coach at the Air Force Academy and later became the head coach of the Pomona-Pitzer Sagehens.

In 1988, Popovich joined the San Antonio Spurs as an assistant coach and eventually became the team’s general manager. In 1996, he took over as the head coach and has remained in that position ever since. Under his leadership, the Spurs have achieved remarkable success, won multiple championships and consistently making the playoffs.

Popovich’s coaching style focuses on team basketball, strong defense, and player development. He has successfully integrated international players into the Spurs’ system and has been recognized for his ability to adapt to different team dynamics. He has also made significant contributions to USA Basketball, serving as both an assistant coach and the head coach of the national team, leading them to a gold medal at the 2020 Summer Olympics.

Off the court, Popovich has been an outspoken advocate for social justice issues and has criticized former President Donald Trump. He has supported various charities and nonprofits, including the San Antonio Food Bank, the Innocence Project, and disaster relief organizations.

Overall, Gregg Popovich’s coaching career is defined by his sustained success, adaptability, and contributions to international basketball. He is widely respected as one of the greatest coaches in NBA history and has made a significant impact both in and outside of the sport.

My comment: Gregg Popovich is an amazing coach. He led spurs to won five times NBA championship, no one will argue about his coaching skill. He can always find the way to maximize the potential of his players. Many players get traded to other team can help their team and cause the chemistry immediately. In Taiwan, people always said player from Spurs is definitely a good player. It’s all count on Popovich’s player development skill. I would say the spirit of this team is Popovich. His cares about team culture. My impression to spurs is their discipline, modesty, and their cohesion. Players and coaches are focus on one thing: win the game. Outside the game, Popovich also cares about players. Tony Parker said his relationship with Pop is like son and father. Most players have played in spurs were grateful of Pop’s instruction. Pop teaches his players more than basketball, but the life, family and so on. Pop now is 74 years old, I don’t know when he will retire. I just hope he can keep making NBA better; influencing, creating more good players; and most importantly, enjoy every game.

David Robinson

David Robinson, known as “the Admiral,” is a former American professional basketball player who played for the San Antonio Spurs in the NBA from 1989 to 2003. He is considered one of the greatest centers in both college basketball and NBA history. Robinson was a 10-time NBA All-Star, the 1995 NBA MVP, and a two-time NBA champion in 1999 and 2003. He also won two Olympic Gold Medals with the United States men’s basketball team in 1992 and 1996. Robinson was inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 2009 for his individual career and in 2010 as a member of the 1992 Olympic team.

Born in Key West, Florida, Robinson’s family moved frequently due to his father’s service in the U.S. Navy. He excelled in school and sports, but his basketball skills were not recognized until a growth spurt during his senior year of high school. Robinson attended the United States Naval Academy, where he became one of the best basketball players in the academy’s history. After graduating, he was selected by the San Antonio Spurs as the first overall pick in the 1987 NBA draft but had to fulfill his active-duty obligation with the Navy before joining the team.

Robinson had an outstanding rookie season, leading the Spurs to a remarkable turnaround and earning the NBA Rookie of the Year award in 1990. He continued to excel, winning the NBA MVP title in 1995 and being named one of the 50 Greatest Players in NBA History in 1996. Despite individual success, Robinson faced playoff disappointments until the 1998-1999 season when the Spurs won their first NBA championship with the help of Tim Duncan. Robinson retired from basketball after the 2002-2003 season, ending his career on a high note with another NBA championship.

Throughout his career, Robinson displayed remarkable athleticism, versatility, and leadership. He averaged 21.1 points, 10.7 rebounds, 3 blocks, and 2.5 assists per game over 987 NBA games. Robinson is also known for his sportsmanship and the strong bond he formed with Tim Duncan, willingly mentoring and accommodating the younger star. In recognition of his contributions to the game, he was named one of the NBA’s 50th Anniversary and 75th Anniversary Teams.

My comment: David Robinson is definitely one of the greatest centers. He can score, rebounding, even play hard on defense. He is an important player in the Spurs history. Besides, he also run the philanthropy, charity. His effort not just on the court, but also off the court. Also, he is humble and kind. He never fights, talk trash with any player. When he was in his heyday, I’m still unborn. After I grow up, I gradually know the Spurs and this great player. I’m admire his dedication on and off the court.

Manu Ginobili

“The Demon Blade”, “The Magician”, “Gino”, “El Contusione”, “Manudona”

Emanuel David Ginóbili Maccari, commonly known as Manu Ginóbili, is an Argentine former professional basketball player. He was born on July 28, 1977. Ginóbili played in the NBA for 16 seasons as a member of the San Antonio Spurs. He is considered one of the greatest shooting guards and sixth men in NBA history.

Ginóbili had a successful career both internationally and in the NBA. He won numerous championships and accolades throughout his career. In his early career, Ginóbili played in Argentina and Italy, where he won several individual and team honors. He joined the San Antonio Spurs in 2002 and became an integral part of the team’s success.

With the Spurs, Ginóbili won four NBA championships in 2003, 2005, 2007, and 2014. He was a key member of the Spurs’ “Big Three” alongside Tim Duncan and Tony Parker. Ginóbili was known for his flashy style of play and was credited with popularizing the Euro step in the NBA. He was also recognized for his clutch performances and ability to impact the game coming off the bench.

In addition to his NBA success, Ginóbili had a successful international career representing Argentina. He won an Olympic gold medal in 2004 and a bronze medal in 2008. He also led the Argentina national team to a second-place finish in the 2002 FIBA World Championship.

Ginóbili retired from the NBA in August 2018 and was announced as a first-ballot inductee into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 2022. He is widely regarded as the greatest Latin American player of all time and has left a lasting impact on the game of basketball.

My comment: Manu is Argentine’s Jordan. He makes people start to value the players from Argentina, makes Argentines start to love basketball. I’m so impressive about what his achievement. Also, his attitude to the team is worth learning. He willing to play substitute, which is very unusual to a great player. When he was on the late stage of his career, he still can stand out, led the players fight back. It is really surprising that he is still competitive when he was 40 years old. I really like his creativity ,energy, and gorgeous scoring skill. He is the first Spurs player I get in touched. 7-11 used to have collaborative merchandise that could be exchanged, and one time they released NBA player magnets. My family exchanged for three, and one of them was Manu. At that time, I didn’t know who this bald guy was, but later I gradually know this great player. I greatly admire his selflessness and contributions to the team.

Tim Duncan

“The Big Fundamental”

Timothy Theodore Duncan, born on April 25, 1976, is a former professional basketball player who played for the San Antonio Spurs of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He is widely regarded as the greatest power forward of all time and one of the greatest players in NBA history. Duncan spent his entire 19-year career with the Spurs and was a key factor in their success during the 2000s and early 2010s. He is a five-time NBA champion, a two-time NBA MVP, a three-time NBA Finals MVP, a 15-time NBA All-Star, and the only player to be selected to both the All-NBA and All-Defensive Teams for 13 consecutive seasons.

Duncan was born and raised on the island of Saint Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands. He initially aspired to be a competitive swimmer but turned to basketball after Hurricane Hugo destroyed the island’s only Olympic-sized pool. In high school, he played basketball for St. Dunstan’s Episcopal School. He then played college basketball for the Wake Forest Demon Deacons, where he achieved numerous accolades including the John Wooden Award and the Naismith College Player of the Year.

After graduating from college, Duncan was selected by the San Antonio Spurs as the first overall pick in the 1997 NBA draft. He formed a formidable partnership with fellow Spurs player David Robinson and the duo was known as the “Twin Towers.” Duncan’s skills, versatility, and basketball IQ made him a dominant force on both ends of the court. He was known for his fundamental playing style, exceptional defense, and consistent performance throughout his career.

Duncan’s career with the Spurs was highly successful. He won five NBA championships with the team in 1999, 2003, 2005, 2007, and 2014. He was also named NBA Finals MVP three times. Duncan’s individual accolades include two NBA MVP awards, 15 NBA All-Star selections, and 15 selections to the All-NBA Team. He retired in 2016 and was inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 2020.

He was the focal point of the team and played a crucial role in their success. Duncan was known for his versatile skills, strong defense, and leadership on and off the court. He won the NBA Finals MVP award in all three championship years and solidified his reputation as one of the greatest power forwards in NBA history.

Along the way, Duncan showcased his trademark consistency and versatility, contributing both offensively and defensively. He displayed his leadership and basketball IQ, making crucial plays and providing stability for the team. In the Finals, Duncan’s impact was significant, as he averaged 15.4 points, 10.0 rebounds, 3.0 assists, and 1.6 blocks per game. His contributions, combined with stellar performances from his teammates, led the Spurs to capture their fifth championship in franchise history.

The victory in the 2013-2014 season further solidified Duncan’s legacy as one of the greatest power forwards in NBA history. He became the first player in NBA history to win championships in three different decades (1999, 2003, 2005, 2007, 2014). Duncan’s longevity, consistency, and ability to adapt to changing circumstances were remarkable, and he continued to be a key contributor for the Spurs even in the later stages of his career.

Late Career and Retirement (2014-2016)

In the following seasons, Duncan continued to play at a high level, providing valuable contributions to the Spurs. However, as he aged, his role on the team began to evolve, with reduced minutes and a decreased offensive load. He embraced his new role as a mentor and leader for the younger players on the team, exemplifying professionalism and dedication.

During the 2015-2016 season, Duncan announced that it would be his final NBA campaign. He received a farewell tour from opposing teams and was honored for his outstanding career. Despite his reduced playing time, Duncan’s impact was still felt on the court, particularly on the defensive end, where he continued to be a reliable presence and anchor for the Spurs’ defense.

In his final season, the Spurs reached the playoffs but were ultimately eliminated in the second round by the Oklahoma City Thunder. Duncan’s last game was on May 12, 2016, ending his illustrious 19-year NBA career. He left the game as one of the most respected and revered players in the history of basketball.

Legacy

Tim Duncan’s impact on the game extends far beyond his individual accolades and championship rings. His fundamentally sound and selfless style of play set a standard for excellence and teamwork. Known for his unassuming demeanor and quiet leadership, Duncan led by example, consistently displaying a high level of professionalism and dedication to his craft.

Duncan’s versatility and basketball IQ allowed him to excel on both ends of the court. He was a dominant force in the paint, renowned for his post moves, rebounding, shot-blocking, and defensive presence. Offensively, he had a reliable mid-range jumper and was known for his bank shots off the glass. His ability to elevate the play of his teammates and make everyone around him better was a testament to his basketball intelligence and unselfishness.

Beyond his on-court achievements, Duncan’s impact was also felt off the court. He embodied the values of loyalty, humility, and teamwork throughout his career, serving as a role model for younger generations of players. Duncan’s professionalism and commitment to the game earned him the respect and admiration of players, coaches, and fans alike.

In recognition of his contributions, Duncan was named to the NBA All-Defensive First Team eight times, NBA All-Defensive Second Team seven times, All-NBA First Team ten times, and All-NBA Second Team three times. He won the NBA Most Valuable Player (MVP) Award twice (2002, 2003) and was selected to the NBA All-Star Game 15 times.

After retiring, Duncan transitioned into a coaching role, joining the San Antonio Spurs as an assistant coach. He continued to contribute his knowledge and experience to the development of young.

My comment: Tim Duncan is a truly great player. When it comes to Spurs players, he is the first person that comes to mind. He dedicated 20 years to this team, and I deeply admire him for that. I also appreciate his personality; he is reserved and humble, letting his actions speak for themselves. That’s why his nickname is “The Big Fundamental”.

Tony Parker

“TP”, “Small French Sports Car”

William Anthony Parker Jr., commonly known as Tony Parker, is a retired French professional basketball player and majority owner of ASVEL Basket in the LNB Pro A. He was born on May 17, 1982, in Bruges, Belgium, and was raised in France. Parker’s father, Tony Parker Sr., played basketball professionally overseas, and his mother, Pamela Firestone, is Dutch. Parker had a passion for soccer initially but switched to basketball after being inspired by the success of Michael Jordan.

Parker began his professional basketball career with Paris Basket Racing in 1999 after playing in the French amateur leagues. In the 2001 NBA draft, he was selected by the San Antonio Spurs as the 28th overall pick. Parker quickly became the team’s starting point guard and played a crucial role in the Spurs’ success. He won four NBA championships with the Spurs in 2003, 2005, 2007, and 2014.

Throughout his career, Parker was named to six NBA All-Star games, received All-NBA honors, and was named the MVP of the 2007 NBA Finals. He also had his jersey number, 9, retired by the Spurs. Parker was known for his speed, agility, and playmaking ability on the court, and he was considered one of the greatest European players of all time.

In addition to his NBA career, Parker represented the French national team and was named the MVP of EuroBasket 2013. He retired as the ninth leading scorer and fifth leading passer in NBA playoffs history. In 2023, Parker was announced as an inductee into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.

After retiring from professional basketball, Parker became the majority owner of ASVEL Basket, a team in the French basketball league. He continues to be involved in

basketball as a coach and mentor.

My comment: Tony Parker is one of the best point guards. He breaks down barriers and stereotypes surrounding European players in the NBA. His achievement inspires many youngsters to play basketball, the basketball become popular in France. On the court, he just like a sports car, penetrate into the paint for direct layups or mid-range jump shots. Tony Parker might not be the most famous point guard, but there are always a place for him. I’m really like his momentum, ambition to become a great player and help the team.

No.1 pick

The NBA Draft Lottery is complete and the San Antonio Spurs will have the No. 1 pick in the 2023 NBA Draft. They are expected to take Victor Wembanyama.

My comment: It is so excited to hear that. Maybe the next Spurs dynasty will come.

Victor Wembanyama

Victor Wembanyama, born on January 4, 2004, is a French professional basketball player who currently plays for Metropolitans 92 in the LNB Pro A. He is considered one of the greatest basketball prospects of all time and is widely projected to be the first overall pick in the 2023 NBA draft by the San Antonio Spurs.

Wembanyama began his professional career with Nanterre 92 in 2019 and later moved to ASVEL, where he won the Pro A title in his only season with the team. In 2022, he signed with Metropolitans 92 and has assumed a leading role on the team. He has been named an LNB All-Star twice and has won the All-Star Game MVP once. Wembanyama is also a two-time LNB Pro A Best Young Player.

At the youth level, Wembanyama has represented the French national basketball team and has led them to two silver medals, including at the 2021 FIBA Under-19 World Cup, where he set the FIBA record for blocks per game in a single tournament.

Wembanyama comes from a family with a strong basketball background. His father, Félix, was a track and field athlete, while his mother, Elodie de Fautereau, is a basketball coach and former player. His older sister, Eve, plays basketball professionally, and his younger brother, Oscar, has also played basketball at the youth level. His grandfather, Michel de Fautereau, and grandmother, Marie Christine, have also played professional basketball.

Wembanyama’s playing style is often described as unique and exceptional. Standing at 7 feet 3 inches (2.21 meters) tall with an estimated 8-foot (240 cm) wingspan, he is one of the tallest players in the league. Despite his height, he possesses excellent mobility, skills, and coordination. He can handle and shoot the ball like a guard, making him a threat both inside and outside the paint. Defensively, his length and anticipation make him a dominant shot-blocker.

However, Wembanyama’s thin frame and lack of strength have been noted as areas for improvement. Opponents often try to use physical play against him to exploit this weakness. Nevertheless, his immense potential and versatility have made him one of the most highly anticipated prospects in recent years, drawing comparisons to the likes of LeBron James.
